content: welcome to the great north of cracking
again today we're gonna do some cool frozen ice pools or ponds right these
are really neat there's a lot of steps of these but they look really great and

[Applause]
my Eureka moment for this project is and
I saw these chopping mats at the Dollar Tree and they're great because they're
see-through they're translucent and they're thick plant there are thick
enough plastic to make it nice and sturdy but not too thick that you can't
see through it so these are perfect and I that's when I got the idea for these
pools I just started out this project by cutting two irregular shapes oval like
shapes and those will be the base for my frozen pools I'm sure you guys have seen
this material it's just packing material that they put in boxes
it's just folded up brown paper and I'm actually gonna recycle this for the
project I took a piece of the packing material and crinkled it up so it would
cover the base of the pond right and this will give a really cool texture
through the ice so then what I did was I just put some glue on it and this will
harden up that surface and make it really nice and solid once the piece is
dry I just cut off the excess okay so so easy and I also glued the bottom put
glue on the bottom to harden up the base now remember when you do put the glue on
the top and the bottom it's gonna tend to work the cardboard so you want to put
some kind of weight on it but make sure that the side is dry to the touch
or you end up gluing the objects to the piece now that those irregular shapes
are all dried up we're gonna trace them on another piece of cardboard okay and
you can see here we got I trace them and I did an interior shape inside of that
shape okay and it's about a centimeter in I just drew it by hand I didn't
really measure and then I cut those out okay and I'm gonna put that on top but
then I'm gonna do it again I'm gonna trace it again and do another shape so
you can see I've got one ring one and ring two here on the photo now the first
thing to do is glue ring one on the top of the other piece the top of the base
and once I have that done I'm gonna put some glue around the interior there and
then I'll put some of my construction sand on there as well as in the center
of the pool and this will hide the corrugation in the piece so that's the
reason for that all righty crafters here we are I
spray-painted a flat black and I'm gonna use a blue gray on this and I'm winning
it quite a bit it's not quite a wash a little more pigment in it than a wash
but it's fairly wet and I'm gonna cover that with that blue grey okay and to
fill that all in now there might be some stones come loose or some above the
surface the edge so I just picked those off and there we go all ready for the
next step now comes the reflection step I've let
my blue gray mostly dry it's not totally dry but I'm dragging this thin brush
across the surface I'm wetting the white quite a bit not like I say not like a
wash but enough that it'll flow easily over the surface because I've got rocks
and that kind of thing that I've got to go over so it helps it to flow you know
over that right over that rough texture so I'm just gonna kind of drag these and
my goal is to make it look like reflections of light under the ice and I
think this is gonna be really cool when I get this done so just kind of drag the
lines over the surface and yeah that's gonna look great I'm loving it look how
cool that's gonna look we get that ice on there I can't wait so there we go
just keep doing until you're satisfied and we'll be going to the next step now
it's time to assemble this bad boy so I've got my glue gun and I cut in a
piece of the cutting sheet and see that's a great thickness of plastic
right so I cut that piece and I'm gonna put it on the top of the other layer of
the first layer and look you can already see looking through that that looks
really really cool right really looks like ice so now I'm gonna glue this
second layer on here second piece of cardboard make sure you get it all on
there and secure that and we're ready to go
here's our piece and it looks really cool but we're kind of stuck with a
problem here it's like how do we hide that edge that lifts off the surface
right so I'm going to use paper towels and a cutting board a no stick cutting
board roll them up like cigars and I'm gonna put these around the edge and this
will kind of hide this height that we build up here with the pool to blend
into the terrain surface right we will move that aside and do the other part
here just spray it like we did it before roll up like a cigar and put it around
the edge add some white glue and that'll hide the fact that it's just you know up
off the surface it'll be a gradual slope and now I'm gonna add my pitch percent
water 50% white glue and that'll harden that up there we go nice now that I have
the edge roughed out I want to smooth it out and I'm gonna use toilet paper it
gives me a finer working detail right gives me it's easier to work with in the
paper towel because the paper towel is a rougher so I'm gonna start adding that
toilet paper around the edge and I don't kind of blend and cover that cardboard
top as well as blend into the rim around the pool here let's keep filling that in
let's see we got it all filled in and now I'm just gonna hit it with 50% water
50% white glue just go around and kind of just tweak it a little bit and now
we're ready let that dry up once the pool dries up I
can remove it from the cutting board that's what nice thing about using a
nonstick surface like that you can just remove it and I just put some white glue
around the edge where the edge meets the base right so that'll help make sure
it's secure then I added some small pebbles the JI got you could you just
grab them out of your yard actually but I got these from Ikea you can get used
fish tank pebbles or that kind of thing and then I embellished it some more with
my construction sand it's just my irregular aggregates and so there we go
now we're ready to paint after this dries so the pools all dry and ready to

so now we got to paint the edge so I'm gonna use a dark brown go around the

get it on the pool if you do that's okay you can wipe it off it's

right so I'm use my flexible modeling paste I really love this stuff don't let

just super easy with the flexible modeling paste now I'm gonna use a

neat effect neat effect after the metallic glue dried I found it was too

and I'm using a damp sponge my damn sponging method and just stipple it on
the surface and you still get those nice that nice sheen coming through you know
and not in the shadows and stuff but it's not on the main highlights so it
kind of works really nicely there so I just covered that up and move on to the
next step looking so good love it onto the final
step and I like to use glitter glue on this type of stuff it gives a really
nice kind of highlight sheen on these like this twinkle and sparkle of snow
and I just squirt it on and spread out it's so much easier than trying to put
